@DeTom48 @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Exactly.  If one section is altered then it is only responsible to consider and remedy the impact on downstream sections and their residents
@_SandraWindsor @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Rivers are very complicated and interactive systems

@DeTom48 @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Very true.  Implementation of the Jubilee River (flood relief channel) has caused extra flooding downstream and the continuation of the relief channel downstream has been cancelled.  So upstream flooding is being transferred downstream into a channel that has not been desilted

@_SandraWindsor @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Not all rivers benefit from this activity - increasing upstream flow can have detrimental affects on downstream communities .. each river needs its own assessments and surveys
@DeTom48 @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Think we need something similar on the Thames

@_SandraWindsor @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Yes it does return the river to full capacity and improve conveyance- we undertake regular silt surveys- sections of river are de silting over a 5 year period to prevent habitat damage - small sections are identified yearly
@DeTom48 @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates So does desilting maintain the channel capacity ?  And if so, how regularly does it need to be done to keep capacity optimised?

@_SandraWindsor @IDBYorkshire @EnvAgencySE @canterburycc @Kent_cc @ADA_updates Chanel maintenance, de silting, is the removal of soft silt on the bed of the river, dredging is removing the bed of the river - two separate activities - de silting returns the river to its natural state - dredging is harmful
